title: About Me Site
body:
This is a site that I built early on in my formal web development learning process.

Disclaimer: This project does not necessarily reflect my current abilities, however I'd love to revisit this at a later time to enhance the navigation area and the interface for the game. I decided to put this up here to remind myself of how far I've come in my adventure of learning how to code websites.

Technologies used: HTML, CSS, Vanilla JavaScript.

title: Donut Shop
body:
This is a forecaster for a fictional set of Donut Shops.

I had a lot of fun with this project beginning by building out the tables using HTML and then gradually adding more functionality through JavaScript to dynamically fill the data in the tables. This taught me how to better utilize JavaScript Objects to store data within an application.

My favorite feature of this is the interactivity where the user can select a specific shop to show as well as update the data within the tables.

Some enhancement ideas include but aren't limited to: adding an input field where the user can add a new shop table to the app as well as adding persistence to store the changes made to the numbers that the user has entered.

title: Vote Tracker
body:
This is an app that allows users to vote on their preferred item, stores the vote, and displays the totals in a graph using the canvasJS library.

An enhancement that I'd like to add would be drag and drop, so the user can reorder the chart items.

This was one of the first times that I've worked with a third party developed JavaScript library and it was a ton of fun.

Technologies used: HTML, CSS, Vanilla JavaScript, and the canvasJS library.

title: Discover Portland
body:
Unsure what to do this weekend? Are you currently in Portland, OR? Well you're in luck, because this site can help suggest fun activities in the area.

This was one of my first collaboration projects using git. My team was looking to solve the problem of not being able to decide what to do when you have visitors from out of town.

Due to time constraints, we decided it was best to use radio buttons for the activity picker, however we're looking to rewrite the logic to allow for checkboxes instead. This way, you wouldn't have to rely on the 'reset' button to clear out the current selections.

This app also keeps the currently selected radio boxes in the browser's local storage, just in case the site visitor navigates away from the page to view an external resource and wants to come back to the activities page just as they left it. My main contribution to this was writing the underlying vanilla JS logic for the radio buttons on the 'activities' page.

title: Rock Paper Scissors
body:
Originally, I built this game to teach myself flow control via if/else statements in JavaScript. However as you can see this turned into a much larger project.

I went down the rabbit hole of Google's developer documentation (which is really amazing btw) and realized that building a Chrome extension was much easier than I originally thought.

Some add ons that I'd like to explore in the future include: adding persistence, so the choices/scores stay in place if you close out of the popup. It would also be neat to refactor this code to be a bit more compact, possibly with a library such as jQuery.

Technologies used: HTML, CSS, Vanilla JavaScript, JSON.

title: Portfolio Blog
body:
You're currently looking at it! Whoa...inception?

This project was a very fun learning experience, and I have many new tools in my belt to apply to future projects.

This was built using an MVC approach along with some functional programming concepts. I also incorporated third party libraries including Handlebars and jQuery. This blog also contains AJAX calls to reference and load the JSON data files for each post. Prior to building out this Blog, I primarily used JavaScript Objects to store data. JSON and AJAX can be very helpful when building larger enterprise level apps.
